The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in the history of mathematics. The most prominent reconstruction programs, those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke, all attempt to provide a purely categorical axiomatization of quantum theory. The present paper provides such an axiomatization.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to P. hydriforme. In addition, our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have important implications for understanding the origin of parasitism. (Show more)

In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity. We also show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex involved in nuclear import. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a molecular understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 is able to evade the host immune response and highlights the importance of Nup98-Rae1 in antiviral defense. The voltage-gated proton channel (Hv1) is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere in the world, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for urgent investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest dietary overlap. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in the maintenance of biodiversity in African savannas. (Abridged)

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, and many are not prepared to weather the crisis. Finally, many businesses are uncertain about the length of the crisis, and they are not confident that they will be able to access the CARES Act programs.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous problem in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by food webs and ballasting processes. This study is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The expansion of the motorized fleet is expected to continue, but the rate of expansion is slowing. The global fleet could reach 5 million vessels by midcentury, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the number of offspring produced in a given period is a fundamental characteristic of all living organisms. This ability is often limited by the mother’s ability to provide for the offspring. Here, we show that the ability to increase the number of offspring produced in a given period is correlated with the ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother. We show that the ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is correlated with the degree of domestication and the practice of allonursing. These results suggest that the ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a fundamental limitation on reproductive output in placental mammals. This result has important implications for the evolution of the placenta and the evolution of domestication. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to protect neurons in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling vascular function, including blood pressure, inflammation, and hemostasis. The endothelium is organized into specialized clusters that are able to communicate with each other and with the surrounding cells. The communication network between these clusters is poorly understood. Here, we show that the communication network between endothelial cells is highly efficient and has a small-world configuration. This configuration is associated with high speed, stability, and synchronizability of the network. These findings reveal the design principles of the endothelial communication network and provide insight into the mechanisms of endothelial function. They also provide a foundation for the development of new technologies to control vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and accessible data is likely to remain high for some time. We describe the COVIDcast API, a system that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic, and we provide a detailed description of the data sources and signals. The COVIDcast API is a valuable resource for researchers and policy makers, and we hope that it will be useful to the broader research community.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and its environment. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is an active area of research, and the potential of the microbiome to produce natural products is an area of interest. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce natural products. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, and that these fungi are a promising source of natural products. This work provides a foundation for future studies to investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce natural products that could be used in the pharmaceutical industry.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy is largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in rats and that this effect is mediated by the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in reward and addiction. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. These findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the complexity of the target behaviors and the material properties. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures that are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically realized. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, can affect the expression of hemoglobin in human erythroblasts. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can mediate the developmental silencing of hemoglobin in adult bone marrow and the reversal of this silencing in fetal liver. This effect is mediated by IGF2BP1 binding to the 3′UTR of the hemoglobin genes and by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/monounsaturated fatty acids signaling, which in turn drives the lipogenesis required for ferroptosis resistance. We also found that the combination of mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is mediated by the STIM Ca2+ sensor. Our findings have important implications for the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP did halt clearcutting on federal land, but this has not been sufficient to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP also created early-seral ecosystems, but these have not been developed in a way that supports the development of older-forest structure. We conclude that the NWFP needs to be strengthened to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the NWFP has been effective in halting the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations. This suggests that the early-seral ecosystem created under the NWFP is a valuable addition to the conservation of early-seral birds. However, the NWFP needs to be strengthened to ensure that the early-seral ecosystem does not impede the development of older-forest structure.

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. We use a combination of in silico and in vitro experiments to test the performance of the designed compounds. We show that the designed compounds are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens and that they can be used in combination with other antibiotics to treat infections caused by these pathogens. The design strategy presented in this work can be used to design new antibiotics against other pathogens.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, and that is easier to train and apply. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales, and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish are a globally unique group of endemic species, which have evolved in a single lake over millions of years. The lake has been a dynamic system, with dramatic changes in lake level and water chemistry, and the fish have responded to these changes. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind, 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability in the tropics, which shows that the lake has been a sensitive indicator of climate change. The fish have been able to track the changing environment, and the rapid evolution of the fish population is a direct result of the changing environment.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin, delays the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning. These effects are likely to be important in the context of the increasing use of such devices, and they have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Ytterby meteorite fell in Sweden in 1739, and its iron-nickel alloy was used as a source of osmium (Os). Osmium is a rare element, and its concentration in bulk samples is often low. The 187Os/188Os ratio is a measure of the terrestrial or meteoritic contribution to the Os in a sample. We show that the 187Os/188Os ratios of bulk samples and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. The 187Os/188Os ratios of spherules from the YDB are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced a wide range of autoimmunity, which was not fatal. However, congenital deficiency was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion had opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance, it is essential for the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to show that beetles diversified in the Carboniferous, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. These novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-SeekBar. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the evolution of the individual than for the evolution of the population. This may be because the individual is the unit of cultural transmission, whereas the population is the unit of cultural reproduction. Our results also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. Finally, our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the evolution of the individual than for the evolution of the population.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is also associated with differential risk for AD. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly phagocytic. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also show that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in astrocytes, which may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses and enhance synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with increased risk for AD due to defective astrocytic phagocytosis. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that APOE4 knock-in mice have increased C1q accumulation in the brain. These studies also suggest that APOE may be a therapeutic target for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. In this study, we find that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, in which the bcc phase is the first nucleus. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. (Abridged)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. The effects of marijuana on the brain are not well understood, and the consequences of chronic marijuana use are unknown. We investigated the effects of marijuana on brain DA reactivity in healthy controls and marijuana abusers. We found that marijuana abusers had blunted brain DA responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular DA in the brain. These findings suggest that marijuana abusers have decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

We present a large-scale, data-driven investigation of the neural and computational mechanisms of language comprehension. We train deep learning models to predict neural and behavioral responses to sentences in multiple datasets and imaging modalities. The models are then used to predict neural and behavioral responses to sentences in a new dataset and imaging modality. The models are also used to predict responses to sentences in the original datasets and imaging modalities, and the accuracy of these predictions is compared to that of a state-of-the-art regression model. The deep learning models outperform the regression model in all cases. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the predictive processing of language may be a general property of human cognition.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is a consequence of the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are not well-conditioned. We introduce a new algorithm, called fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which is stable and converges to a solution with high probability. We also prove that only a small number of layers are needed to achieve a given accuracy. Our results provide a classification theory for the existence of algorithms that compute stable NNs in inverse problems. This theory can be extended to other problems in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a textbook example of how the failure to understand exponential growth can have deadly consequences. The first case of COVID-19 was reported in China in December 2019, and the first death in Europe in January 2020. By the end of March 2020, the number of cases and deaths had grown exponentially. To understand the pandemic, it is essential to understand exponential growth. This is a phenomenon that is so counterintuitive that it is often cited as an example of how people fail to understand it. However, the experiment that is often cited as the “proof” that people fail to understand exponential growth has several critical design flaws. These flaws were not recognized at the time, and the study was widely cited as proof of the failure to understand exponential growth. In this article, we discuss the flaws of the study and how they undermine its conclusion.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and yet we still do not understand the mechanisms that cause the disease. We sequenced the genome of a patient with leprosy and found that it is very similar to the genome of the leprosy bacillus, which has been studied extensively. This suggests that the leprosy bacillus has not changed much since it was first discovered, and that the disease has not changed much since ancient times.

The dynamics of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the steady state. This result is valid for both unitary and dissipative dynamics, and it is exact for integrable models. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we provide a detailed analysis of the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit for the free fermion system. Our results pave the way to the study of the dynamics of entanglement in generic quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in more than 200,000 deaths in the United States and more than 4.5 million deaths worldwide. The only vaccine currently available for use in the United States is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. We describe a vaccine that is based on a live, attenuated virus that is being developed by our laboratory. The vaccine is designed to be administered intranasally, which is a simple and safe route of administration. The vaccine is also designed to be very safe, with a very low potential for causing disease. The vaccine is also designed to be highly protective, with the potential to protect against all variants of concern. These features, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, support its potential use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and death. It is also a disease that is still a threat to human health, as evidenced by the recent outbreaks in Central Asia. In this study, we developed a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for understanding the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases.

The brain is the most complex organ in the human body. It is also the most plastic, allowing us to learn new skills and adapt to new environments. The evolution of the brain is therefore a key question in the history of life. The brain is made of neurons, the cells that transmit information. We show that the evolution of brain neurons is different in reptiles, birds, and mammals. This has important implications for the study of the evolution of brain size and cognitive ability.

The molecular chaperone TRAP1 is found predominantly in mitochondria. It is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between HSP90 and TRAP1, making their utility as probes of TRAP1-specific function questionable. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the cytoskeletal elements that are most frequently disassembled and reassembled in cells. The cofilin proteins are the main regulators of this process. However, how cofilin cuts filaments is not understood. Here, we show that the mechanical torque exerted by cofilin on filaments is the key to understanding the mechanism of cofilin action. We propose that this mechanism is critical to the ability of cofilin to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. This mechanism may also be relevant to other processes, such as the assembly of microtubules.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and its relationship to the development of eating disorders.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island shows that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it will be useful for the management of the island. It will also be useful for the study of the history of the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people’s emotions are transferred to others without their awareness. We show that this effect is not limited to in-person interaction, and that it is not limited to positive emotions. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that is responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that are important for translation. In this work, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in messenger RNA can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We find that the presence of Ψ can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our findings suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA and that this can have a modest impact on translation. This work provides a new perspective on the role of mRNA modifications in the ribosome and the protein synthesis machinery. (Show more)

This study shows that a sense of the things one does in life being worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social engagement, and a healthier lifestyle. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to test the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven toward a common body size in the water. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is the most common viral infection in the world, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of upper respiratory tract infection. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the human body is unknown. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicate more efficiently at the temperature found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus and may help to explain the high rate of rhinovirus infection in the human population. (Show more)

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment, and many of these systems are involved in the regulation of virulence. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces. This mechanism is important for the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and virulence. We propose a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of the pili is sensed by a chemosensory system, and the resulting signal is amplified by a positive feedback loop. This mechanism is important for the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and virulence. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and the regulation of virulence. They also have implications for the development of antimicrobial strategies.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more. However, the consequences of these changes on the quality of surface water are largely unknown. We show that the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels for surface water and sediments. This risk is high even in countries with stringent environmental regulations. Thus, the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. We recommend worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global pesticide contamination of surface water and sediments. It is the first of its kind to our knowledge. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns that the virus could reemerge in a susceptible animal population, leading to a resurgence of human infections. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a free-living animal species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 has been circulating in deer since the onset of the pandemic in humans. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to monitor and mitigate the spread of SARS-CoV-2 in wildlife. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of large dams, the problems they cause, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of amyloid plaques. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques, but this study demonstrates that the Aβ-burdened neuron is the primary source of inflammation in the brain. We show that the Aβ-burdened neuron is the primary source of inflammation in the brain. We also demonstrate that the human brain is vulnerable to this neuron-specific inflammatory response, suggesting that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a significant contributor to the human disease.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. Here we present evidence that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are not known for most proteins. However, the folding of a few proteins has been studied in great detail, and the results are used to infer the general folding process. This work adds another protein to the list of those that fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results also suggest that the 7-s intermediate is a common step in the folding of other proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. However, the cellular decapping enzyme responsible for removing those caps is not known. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove Np4-capped 5′ termini, also removes dinucleoside diphosphate (d NDP) capped 5′ termini. This enzyme uses a unique mechanism to recognize the 5′ ends of RNA, with the δ-phosphate of the cap serving as the nucleophile for the attack on the β-phosphate of the nucleoside. This discovery has implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress, as the removal of Np4 caps is critical for the rapid degradation of those RNAs. Understanding the mechanisms by which cells regulate gene expression in response to stress could lead to the development of new strategies for controlling gene expression in bacteria. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor prognosis. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression in sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We highlight that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, including quantum computing, photonics, and energy storage. However, its properties are difficult to control and tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned from indirect to direct. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for applications in quantum computing, photonics, and energy storage. They also provide a platform for exploring the role of strain in the formation of diamond nanostructures. Our findings are expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in animals has led to the development of a new class of antibiotics. However, the discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants is still in its infancy. Here, we report the discovery of a plant antifungal peptide, NCR044, which is highly active against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The structure of the peptide was solved by NMR spectroscopy, and it was found to be highly dynamic and disordered. The peptide was found to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides, and to penetrate the fungal cell wall and membrane. The peptide was found to be active against plant fungal pathogens, and to reduce disease symptoms in plants. This work provides a basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is the first report of a plant antifungal peptide with such activity. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the viability of sperm. We also show that the male–female axis is more complex than previously thought, as sperm initially associate with seminal fluid proteins, but these seminal fluid proteins are lost after sperm are stored in the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a key component of the blood clotting system. It binds to platelets, where it mediates blood clotting. The binding reaction is triggered by alterations in flow, which are common during bleeding. We show that the binding reaction can be switched to a faster state by force, which is a common phenomenon in the body. This mechanism provides a way to explain the pathophysiology of the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease. The mechanism is also relevant to other diseases, such as thrombosis.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to study the impact of viruses on human health. This study addresses this gap, and provides a resource for the community to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI is complex and difficult to be observed. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe simultaneously aerosol and cloud properties. The HSRL is expected to be a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI investigations.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of intense debate for more than a century. The most widely accepted estimate of surface temperature in the Archean, the earliest geologic period of Earth, is 70 ± 15 °C. This estimate is based on isotopic evidence, however, and has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic record, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. Here, we present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell and are regulated by multiple mechanisms. The activation gate is the main site of regulation for fast channel opening and closing. The C-type inactivation gate is the main site of regulation for slow C-inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel lacks an intracellular activation gate and instead has a C-type inactivation gate at the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses its erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, to alter the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the malaria parasite is not simply trying to push its way through the RBC, but is instead using a number of physical interactions to prime the RBC surface for invasion. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned from indirect to direct. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for applications in quantum computing, photonics, and energy storage. They also provide a platform for exploring the relationship between elastic and electronic properties in solids. Our findings are expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may provide a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to show that the brain builds phrases by merging words. We found that the brain increases its activity whenever it merges a word into a phrase, and that the merge operation is applied equally to words and to phrases. Our results suggest that the brain implements a bottom-up parser of the incoming language stream that is able to merge words into phrases. This parser is likely to be important for the comprehension of spoken language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway in development and homeostasis. It is also a pathway that is dysregulated in many cancers. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, and that this differential regulation confers differential responsiveness to the pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit that includes dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra, and that the LH circuit is not involved in the regulation of feeding. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil is therefore a key trait for plants. However, the nitrogenase enzyme, which catalyzes the conversion of atmospheric N2 to a form that plants can use, is highly inefficient. Therefore, the ability to control the timing and location of nitrogen fixation is a key goal for sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate a system that allows for the control of nitrogen fixation in barley, a cereal crop, by the bacterium that colonizes its roots. This system provides a platform for the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The program may have increased the perceived authority of monitors and reduced the ability of unincentivized citizen patrols to inhibit timely detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize the source of sound, which is essential for survival. The hearing organs of animals are all part of the body, and their size is constrained by the size of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear by outsourcing its hearing to its web, which is made of protein. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, and the spider can remotely detect and localize the source of sound. The spider can also supersize its web to increase its acoustic sensitivity. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic sensors. It also provides a unique model for studying the sensing and regeneration of the external body. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. Here we report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which is well-established as a vaccine antigen. The variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. The engineered RBD is presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD may be a useful vaccine antigen.

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric cancer. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALs activate the zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro. Zebrafish ALKAL loss-of-function mutants show defects in the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. These results provide in vivo evidence for the activation of ALKALs in vivo and their involvement in neural crest development. This study provides a basis for further studies on the role of ALKALs in human cancer and in neural crest development. Furthermore, the zebrafish system can be used to study the role of ALKALs in other tissues and organs.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-established hypothesis. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical time period for understanding the origins of the plague. We find that the Y. pestis lineage remained relatively stable over time, with a single lineage persisting over millennia. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Abridged)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to croplands has led to the release of 1.2 Pg C of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) to the atmosphere annually. This study shows that the management of grasslands and croplands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil.
